page.title: 01LITTLE BADDOW VILLAGE
page.content: Little Baddow is a small rural village approximately 15km east of Chelmsford in Essex. There is evidence from the Domesday Book that Little Baddow was a prosperous farming community. Before 1066 it was owned by Leofwin but after the Conquest William I saw fit to divide the area into two parts which were held by Lambert and Germund and were worth Â£6 each. Since Norman times the economy of the village has changed little, its wealth is still in the land, which is now used for arable farming. Much of the decidious woodland areas remain. The village is sited on the rise of a small hill at about 75m above sea level. The settlement follows a linear pattern stretching for 1km. The population of Little Baddow in 1985 was approximately 2000.
